basics.name: Abed Garra
basics.label: M.Sc. Student in Computer Science
basics.summary: Computer Science M.Sc. student at Tel Aviv University working at the intersection of computer security and machine learning, with a focus on systems-oriented security analytics and trustworthy ML.

education.summary: Advisor: Dr. Mahmood Sharif. Thesis: Reliable Security-Incident Prediction from Text and Network Measurements.

awards.title: High School Excellence Scholarship for University Studies
awards.summary: Merit-based scholarship awarded for academic excellence; covered full undergraduate tuition.

work.name: Tel Aviv University
work.summary: Mentored students through real-world ML-based security projects.
highlights: Workshop on Usable Security and Privacy (Dr. Mahmood Sharif)
Workshop on Intrusion Detection with ML (Dr. David Movshovitz)

work.name: Tel Aviv University
work.summary: Evaluated correctness and robustness of student implementations in C and Python.
highlights: Tested multiple variants of the K-Means algorithm
Used Valgrind to verify memory allocations and detect leaks

work.name: Tel Aviv University
highlights: Clarified core concepts and guided formal mathematical writing
Designed personalized study plans and prepared students for final exams

projects.name: Reliable Security-Incident Prediction from Text and Network Measurements
projects.description: M.Sc. thesis project studying how public signals can be used to forecast organization-level security incidents under realistic constraints.
highlights: Built an end-to-end forecasting pipeline using geopolitical news and Internet-wide measurements
Processed CC-News archives using DataTrove for filtering and deduplication
Fine-tuned Longformer (MLM) and implemented multi-GPU distributed training with PyTorch DDP

projects.name: Fingerprinting Embedding Models for Black-Box Retrieval
projects.description: Research project investigating input‚Äìoutput level profiling methods for identifying embedding models under black-box access.
highlights: Studied stability and transferability of semantic similarity patterns across models
Focused on system-level implications of opaque ML components

projects.name: advEGI: Transferability in Ego-Graph Information Maximization
projects.description: Course project revisiting EGI (NeurIPS 2021) with a focus on adversarial training and transferability.
highlights: Implemented PGD-style adversarial pretraining under budgeted edge perturbations
Found transfer gains to be inconsistent, with simple baselines often competing strongly
